body.p: “Man cannot be established by wickedness” (Proverbs XII. 3)

My friends! The present is not a season for recriminations. I will not administer now
the scathing rebuke which they will deserve who in their political harangues have
dispersed? the fair name of Israel. Were I ever inclined to analyze at the bar of your
impartial opinion individuals who abused their positions by conjuring up the demoniac
Hurt of prejudice against my people, I would be restrained by the magnanimous crumple
of our chief Executive. He, than whom none could be more vilified by his opponents,
appeals to God as a witness, that animosity does not rankle in his breast.
Yes, I will say it with the ancient moralist “Hatred stirreth up strife, but love
covereth all sins” The heart that throbs with undying affection for the Union, can
forgive the offense of some of its narrow-minded children. We my Brethren—the
representatives of a sublime Truth, for the preservation of which we have suffered and
bled, ought never to judge of the merits of a preamble from the illiberality of some
who profess to advocate it. We ought, under all circumstances though unjustly held in
contempt, to triumph over the strides taken by our fellow-men toward the attainment
of glorious ends. Therefore upon this day, when the harmonious voice of loyalty is raised
to heaven with thanksgivings and praises, the worshipper of a Unity should duly be forced
among mid the national chorus of that In celebrates the victories of the Union. But I see, I have,
for the sake of a rhetorical flourish, employed an incorrect expression. Not the victories
of the Union, but those of Freedom, my friends, we do celebrate. What is Union with
human degradation. Who would again affix his seal to the bond that resigned millions
to ?dom? Not I, the enfranchised slave of Myraim. Not you, whose motto is progress
and civilization least then your version yonder, and behold the happy change wrought by the
hand of Providence. When the ? which summoned all to arms, resounded throughout this
land, a band of patriots vowed to set high upon Fort Sumter the flag that treason had
lowered to the earth. Who arose then to impede their work? The men of a state which
has now buried in the waters of the Potomac the shackles of servitude. She blushed at a deed
that had stained her escutcheon, and timely laid on the national altar, an offering of atonement.
Her momentary indiscretion misled the foe, therefore she was comitted by the adversaries of a universal
freedom. They coquetted with her, who fancied that she would be easily ? by their acts, but
she withstood the seduction, and voluntarily cast her lot among the free & the brave. My name
shall no longer be called Maryland but merry-land for thou hast verily breathed in joyous spirit
into the souls of thy inhabitants. And when I remember, my friend, that from the windows
of our legislative hall a scene could be witnessed, two years ago, that belied the enactments of
a Republican Senate, I discover, with a naked eye, the finger of the Almighty Creator working
wonders.

The District of Columbia gave the first impulse to the wheel of progress, and it has ever since
rolled on with a steady motion. My beloved hearers! If this alone were the issue? of our struggle, it
would suffice the philanthropist. It would offer him ample occasion to pour forth sincere thanksgivings
for the benevolence of his unfortunate fellow-beings. But we have also taught the world thereby
a lesson of incalculable utility Aye “man cannot be established by wickedness”. A few ambitious men
because they could not yet as chiefs in all high places, sought to destroy the happiness of their country.
But the fore-brand which they threw in her midst has very nigh well devoured their vitals. God who
abhors inequity confounded their counsel. Innumerable were the means which they employed to divide
and conquer. The diplomatic skill in which they confidently abound, undaunted courage, a power of
resistance worthy of a holy cause, all the appliances of science, all the dexterity of arts, were resorted to
by the leaders of factions and their deluded followers to fasten upon the North ruin and disgrace,
but they conceived vanity and brought forth naught. England, envious of he our greatness, may
have in an earl hour for herself, lent them her moral or rather immoral aid. Her Majesty of
France who ascended the throne by treading upon the corpses of revolutionary victims, may have inspired
the hope of an early recognition, but the display of our collossal strength rendered our enemies ?
of their promises. Thus frustrated in all their schemes, those whites of the South that have rebelled against
legitimate authority, let loose now their piratical agents, and an unbridled soldiery to devastate our
fields and prey on our commerce, but “man cannot be established by wickedness. Gettysburg and the
Shenandoah Valley tell the flight of the invading host; the ? and Wachusset prove his
impotency. The fate of a confederacy founded upon fraud has been sealed above. The conqueror of
Atlanta will dismantle its ramparts; the hero of Vicksburg will make an end of its rule.
But say they, who from feelings of humanity are averse to blood-shed. How dearly will our final victory
be bought!” It may cost the lives of thousands of our promising youths; it may cover the face of
the land with the pall of death; we may again and again be startled by the shreeks of desolate
mothers; we may behold the crushing sorrow of fathers. My kind-hearted friends! I also share
with you the horror which war inspires, and could I have averted it from this country of our love,
no sacrifice would have been deemed too great. I would have even yielded a cherished desire, which
pervades my very soul—that of universal liberty—and trusted to God, who might in His good time
bring it to pass, but the gage was thrown at our feet. We must either accept it, or bear
upon our foreheads the mark of ignominy. What American will hesitate how to choose in the
alternative? To stake his existence at the battle-field in the defense of the Stars and Stripes, or to
be the contempt of people and the derision of Kings? Life is a precious gift, but the poltroon who
to preserve it sells his country and his rights, is a worthless carcass. Besides, it appears (may I
not sin of impiety) it appears as thought the fiat of the Omnipotent was that great truths
must wend their course through blood ere they are firmly established upon earth. It may be with
the wise design that their value be enhanced in our estimation, that they may me be rendered dearer
to all hearts. But what ever may be the inscrutable motive, we cannot expect that for our sake
the divine decree will be altered. Deploring therefore, the dire necessity of war, we must not sh?

from it, when the life of a nation hangs thereupon. The heros of your revolution, those
noble names “that grace the rolls of fame” went boldly forth to the conflict, because they
preferred death to foreign subjugation. Not the thirst of blood stirred them up, but the
conviction that from its reeking mass the genius of Liberty would rise. Your Montgomery and
Your Warrens, who breathed their last mid the roar of the cannon, were the instruments by which
the God of battles, wrought the happiness of a whole generation. True, the men they gallantly
fought were not the children of this soil—brothers nurtured at the same breast. They were
the sons of the stranger, who attempted to rule over us. Now, alas! we are marshaled in mortal
array against the offspring of our kind mother. But upon them, who first unsheathed the
fritricidal sword rests the terrible responsibility. Unnatural and perfidious they endeavoured to sunder
at a stroke that bond of union which constitutes our greatness. That which ? is the glory of America,
and the joy of the oppressed they would demolish, to rear upon its ruin a monument to human bondage.
It shall not be. The thundering voice of millions of among the free has so proclaimed. Upon the
day that the suffrage of a sovereign people was to declare in whose hands they shall trust their
interests during another cycle of years, my anxious looks were directed to the wires whereby intelli
=gence is spread abroad. The air had been previously filled with inauspicious rumors. The
most incredulous believed that the mighty contest would surely give birth to violence and sedition.
My friends! We have won many battles, but the last was the most decisive. It cut off the
remaining prop upon which the fungus confederacy rested for support. No more can it trust on
for success in the diversity of our political opinions. Every man exercised his elective franchise
agreeably to his best judgment, but even they who bestow an undue degree of pity on our misguided
foes refused to lead countenance to treason. The dreaded clamour of angry multitudes was not heard
in our borders, the threats of disaffection found no utterance in our midst. I called challenged
the world to show a parallel case. Of a nation, I say, wrought up to the highest pitch of
political effervescence who, nevertheless regulate their actions by the square and compass of equity.
Let now the foreign press indite its diatribes about man's inability for self government. We
have proved our capacity for it. We have proved moreover, that we are resolved at all hazards,
to bequeath to posterity the country founded by our Washington in all its untarnished lustre.
Once more will we call upon the rebellious to desist “Return ye wayward children; your
trespasses shall be remembered no more” If they hearken, we will “beat our swords into plough-shares,
and our spears into pruning-hooks.” If they harden their hearts, we shall lament so much contumacy,
but its disastrous effects shall be required at their hands. Oh! Let us pray that they may heed our call.
Let us in all sincerity tender the olive branch. Let us endeavour by honorable means to facilitate its
acceptance. More than in the prowess of our army and the feats of our navy we ought to seek
glory in laboring peacefully for the reconstruction of our once mighty Republic. Our progress in
arts and sciences, which thus uh unhappy war has caused to develop will sink into utter insignific
=ance before the progress which all the human race shall attain, when tutored by a nation whose laws

are the laws of righteousness and whose sole defense is peace. Oh! Let us pray for the
dawning of that joyous day when thirty five reunited States shall offer a national
thanksgiving, while the symbol of their greatness shall proudly wave over every
dome and sphere. Let us pray for peace.

Parent of good! We lay prostrate at the footstool of Thy mercy and crave for peace.
Grateful for Thy manifold favors at all times and this year especially, we yet cannot fully
rejoice in its fruition. Thou hast verily filled to overflowing the cup of our prosperity, but
that of bitter sorrow is also brought nigh to our lips. The aspect of the dead, the
agony of the wounded, the moaning of the sufferers, tear our hearts. From the
ensanguinedbattle field, from the chilly and dreary camps, from the bereaved and lonely
hearth, a voice rises unto Thee, O compassionate Lord! and “peace, peace” it cries. Oh I send
a ray of Divine wisdom to illumme the mind of our Chief Magistrate, that he may discover
the instrument of peace. Let the gentle spirit of forbearance hover around the Assembly
of our Senators and Le Representatives and guide their deliberations. Repress the vehemence
of zealots, and let the feelings of the obdurate be softened by tokens of brotherhood and love.
May we speedily throw again My holy courts, to thank and praise Thy name, Oh most
High God! for the longed-for peace of our beloved Union.

And now I beseech Thee O Lord! to excite within us a sentiment of patriotism, that we may
enlist our names among these of our beneficent men and women who labor for the sake of our
defenders at sea and on land. May our hospitals, our sanitary commissions and our
soldiers and societies obtain a ready and generous cooperation from those who have been taught
to believe that “Charity delive delivereth from death”. May such be Thy gracious will, O
Heavenly Creator. Amen.
A thanksgiving discourse for the year 1864
